layman:
**History of Present Illness**  
The patient came in today because he feels lightheaded and has trouble keeping his balance. He says it is not the spinning feeling he has had before with vertigo; it is just a strong sense of lightheadedness. It usually happens when he changes position, such as standing up from sitting or lying down. Sitting down again helps a little, but the feeling can last 15 to 30 minutes and he feels shaky and weak all over. Lorazepam did not help. His blood pressure has been high lately, and his metoprolol dose was increased. He thinks the symptoms have gotten worse since the dose was raised.

**Past Medical History**  
(See our H&P form.) The patient has high cholesterol, diabetes, glaucoma, cataracts, high blood pressure, heart disease, a history of vertigo, a stroke in May 2005, congestive heart failure, coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), and a cataract removed from his right eye.

**Current Medications**  
(See our H&P form.)

**Physical Examination**  
Blood pressure while sitting: 180/80, pulse 56. Blood pressure while standing: 160/80, pulse 56. General and neurological exams are on the H&P form. Notable findings on the neurological exam include decreased sensation on the left side of his face, left arm, and left leg.

**Impression and Plan**  
The patientâ€™s lightheadedness is not the same as his past vertigo; it is more of a general lightheaded feeling. He had a mild drop in blood pressure during the visit. We are also concerned that a slow heart rate (bradycardia) might be contributing to his lightheadedness. We will arrange for a Holter monitor and advise him to discuss the symptoms with his primary doctor and cardiologist. The Holter monitor will be scheduled, and he will be referred back to his cardiologist.
